channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2024 The New York Times Company

item.title: Live Updates: U.S. and Qatar Say Gaza Cease-Fire Talks Will Resume, but Offer Few Details
item.description: Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken said U.S. and Qatari negotiators would soon restart long-stalled negotiations, but that it remained unclear if Hamas was willing to engage.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times

item.title: Is Afghanistan’s Most-Wanted Militant Now Its Best Hope for Change?
item.description: Sirajuddin Haqqani has tried to remake himself from blood-soaked jihadist to pragmatic Taliban statesman. Western diplomats are shocked — and enticed.
item.dc:creator: Christina Goldbaum
item.media:credit: Jim Huylebroek for The New York Times
item.media:description: Sirajuddin Haqqani during an interview in Kabul, Afghanistan, in March.

item.title: What We Learned Talking to the Taliban’s Most Fearsome Leader
item.description: Sirajuddin Haqqani, who has a $10 million American bounty on his head, is now positioning himself as a figure of relative moderation.
item.dc:creator: Christina Goldbaum
item.media:credit: Jim Huylebroek for The New York Times
item.media:description: Sirajuddin Haqqani during an interview with The New York Times in Kabul, Afghanistan.

item.title: At BRICS, Putin Appears to Say That North Korean Troops Are in Russia
item.description: ‘If there are images they are a reflection of something,’ he said in a tongue-in-cheek answer to whether Pyongyang had sent troops to help with Russia’s war in Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Valerie Hopkins
item.media:description: Russian President Vladimir V. Putin did not explicitly confirm or deny remarks made Wednesday by the Pentagon, which said that North Korea had sent troops to Russia.

item.title: Metula, Israeli Town on Lebanon Border, Worries for Its Future
item.description: Abandoned and off limits to civilians, Metula, a symbol of early pioneering Zionism, is left half-ruined by Hezbollah’s rockets and missiles.
item.dc:creator: Isabel Kershner and Sergey Ponomarev
item.media:description: Metula, in northern Israel, has been heavily damaged by Hezbollah’s rockets and missiles amid tensions between the armed group and Israel.

item.title: 5 Key Questions Hanging Over the Lucy Letby ‘Killer Nurse’ Case
item.description: Ms. Letby, a neonatal nurse in England found guilty of murdering seven babies, has lost a fresh appeal bid. A growing number of experts have raised concerns about the evidence.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia
item.media:description: The nurse Lucy Letby was found guilty last year of the murder of seven babies and the attempted murder of six others.

item.title: Lucy Letby, Former U.K. Nurse, Loses Bid to Appeal Attempted Murder Conviction
item.description: Ms. Letby is serving 15 life sentences after the deaths and collapses of babies in the neonatal unit where she worked.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia
item.media:description: The Women and Children’s Building at the Countess of Chester Hospital in Chester, north west England.

item.title: U.K. Plans Disposable Vape Ban in England
item.description: The measure, which echoes plans in Scotland and Wales, aims to protect young people’s health and reduce environmental damage.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Castle
item.media:description: Using a single-use vaping product in London in 2023.

item.title: Chapo Wins Mozambique’s Presidency in Disputed Election
item.description: Daniel Chapo of the Frelimo party, which has governed the southern African nation for nearly 50 years, was declared the victor amid violence and widespread allegations of fraud.
item.dc:creator: John Eligon
item.media:description: Supporters of Daniel Chapo, the Frelimo candidate who was declared the winner of Mozambique’s presidential election, in Maputo this month.

item.title: How Powerful Is North Korea’s Military?
item.description: The North’s nuclear forces have been the focus of global concern. But its conventional military is vast and empowered — even if it is hobbled by shortages, corruption and isolation.
item.dc:creator: Choe Sang-Hun
item.category: Arms Control and Limitation and Disarmament
item.media:description: The North Korean military, officially the Korean People’s Army, is the world’s fourth-largest. It has 1.3 million active-duty soldiers and another 7.6 million in the reserves.

item.title: India Evacuates 1 Million as Tropical Cyclone Dana Nears
item.description: With the storm forecast to make landfall by early Friday, residents in parts of West Bengal and Odisha States took shelter in thousands of camps.
item.dc:creator: John Yoon and Pragati K.B.
item.media:description: Passengers at a train station facing cancellations in the Indian state of West Bengal on Wednesday before the arrival of Tropical Storm Dana.

item.title: Putin Abandons Caution on North Korea in Pursuit of Victory in Ukraine
item.description: The invasion of Ukraine has led the Russian leader to jettison cooperation with the West over North Korea’s nuclear arsenal in favor of an ever-deepening military alliance with Pyongyang.
item.dc:creator: Anatoly Kurmanaev and Choe Sang-Hun
item.category: Arms Control and Limitation and Disarmament
item.media:description: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russian and Kim Jong-un, North Korea’s leader, at a state reception in Pyongyang in June, in a photo released by Russian state media.

item.title: World Opens to the Taliban Despite Their Shredding of Women’s Rights
item.description: Taliban officials have scored a series of diplomatic victories this year that have started a subtle shift toward normalizing their government.
item.dc:creator: Christina Goldbaum
item.media:description: A photograph released by the United Arab Emirates Presidential Court showing President Mohamed bin Zayed al-Nahyan, right, meeting with a delegation from Afghanistan’s Taliban administration, including Sirajuddin Haqqani, in Abu Dhabi in June.

item.title: What We Know About the Militant Attack in Turkey
item.description: After the assault on an aerospace complex in Ankara, Turkey struck sites of the Kurdistan Workers’ Party and its affiliates in Syria and Iraq.
item.dc:creator: Ben Hubbard
item.media:description: Emergency workers rushed to the headquarters of Turkey’s state-run aerospace company, near the capital, Ankara, on Wednesday.

item.title: Why the World Fears a War Between Israel and Iran
item.description: An all-out war could entangle countries around the world and threaten the global economy.
item.dc:creator: Victoria Kim
item.media:description: A destroyed building in Hod Hasharon, Israel, after an Iranian missile attack earlier this month.

item.title: U.N. Report on Climate Goals Says Countries Have Made No Progress
item.description: An annual assessment by the world body tracks the gulf between what countries have vowed to do and what they’ve actually achieved.
item.dc:creator: Brad Plumer
item.category: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change
item.media:description: A natural gas field in Bolivia. Though renewable energy sources are growing rapidly around the world, demand for electricity has been rising even faster.

item.title: Why Democracy Lives and Dies by Math
item.description: A documentary filmmaker and a mathematician discuss our fear of numbers and its civic costs.
item.dc:creator: Siobhan Roberts
item.media:credit: Anastasiia Sapon for The New York Times
item.media:description: Vicki Abeles, director of the new documentary, “Counted Out,” which explores the intersection of mathematics, civil rights and democracy.

item.title: How a Binance Employee Strained the Relationship Between the U.S. and Nigeria
item.description: The United States and Nigeria often collaborate. But the arrest of an American worker strained their diplomatic relations.
item.dc:creator: Julian E. Barnes, David Yaffe-Bellany and Emily Flitter
item.media:description: Tigran Gambaryan leaving a court hearing in Abuja, Nigeria, in April. His release came after months of diplomatic pressure by the United States and in return for promises of an improved partnership with Nigeria.

item.title: 3 Arrested in Sri Lanka Over Possible Threats Against Israeli Tourists
item.description: The arrests, all of Sri Lankans, came a day after the U.S. and Israel issued warnings to its citizens to avoid a popular tourist area.
item.dc:creator: Claire Moses
item.media:description: A police officer in Arugam Bay in Sri Lanka on Wednesday.

item.title: Israeli Attack Killed 3 More of Its Soldiers in the South, Lebanon Says
item.description: Israel’s military said it was looking into whether its forces had “accidentally harmed” Lebanese soldiers while conducting raids in southern Lebanon against Hezbollah.
item.dc:creator: Liam Stack
item.media:description: Smoke rising over the southern outskirts of Beirut on Thursday.

item.title: New Pope Francis Encyclical Urges Catholics to Reject Individualism
item.description: In an encyclical titled “He Loved Us,” Francis draws on spiritual themes in the hopes of helping people find deeper meaning while living in today’s hectic societies.
item.dc:creator: Emma Bubola
item.media:description: Pope Francis in St. Peter’s Square at the Vatican on Wednesday. His latest missive focuses of “the importance of the heart.”

item.title: E.P.A. Toughens Requirements to Remove Lead Paint Dust Around Children
item.description: The new rules consider any detectable level of lead dust in a building a “lead hazard,” requiring property owners to pay for cleanup.
item.dc:creator: Hiroko Tabuchi
item.media:description: Lead-based paint for residential use was banned in 1978, but the E.P.A. estimates that 31 million older dwellings still contain lead paint.

item.title: Cambodia Journalist Who Exposed Scams Is Released on Bail
item.description: Mech Dara spent three weeks in detention after he was charged for posts he made online. He still faces a charge of “incitement to provoke social chaos.”
item.dc:creator: Sui-Lee Wee and Sun Narin
item.media:description: Mech Dara, a Cambodian journalist, after he was released from detention on Thursday.

item.title: Thursday Briefing: How Europe Sees the U.S. Election
item.description: Plus, the dark side of A.I. companionship apps.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost and Justin Porter
item.media:description: Donald Trump and Kamala Harris are essentially tied in the polls.

item.title: Shiori Ito’s Searing Documentary ‘Black Box Diaries’ to Open in U.S.
item.description: “Black Box Diaries,” a documentary about Shiori Ito’s fight against Japan’s patriarchal justice system, opens on Friday in the United States.
item.dc:creator: Motoko Rich
item.media:credit: Shiho Fukada for The New York Times
item.media:description: Shiori Ito made a documentary on her experience fighting against Japan’s patriarchal justice system after she became the face of #MeToo in Japan.

item.title: Israel Bombs Lebanese City as Blinken Hints at New Ideas for Gaza Cease-Fire
item.description: The Israeli military struck targets in the port city of Tyre on Wednesday, the latest phase of a bombardment campaign against the militant group Hezbollah.
item.dc:creator: Euan Ward, Michael Crowley, Aaron Boxerman and Thomas Fuller
item.media:description: Israel attacked the ancient Lebanese port city of Tyre on Wednesday after issuing its broadest evacuation order there so far.

item.title: Thursday Briefing: How the U.S. Election is Viewed Abroad
item.description: Plus, the dark side of A.I. companionship apps.
item.dc:creator: Gaya Gupta
item.media:description: Kamala Harris and Donald Trump during the presidential debate last month.

item.title: At BRICS Summit, One of Putin’s Guests Stands Out: Turkey’s President
item.description: President Vladimir V. Putin, hoping to prove he is not the pariah that the West has tried to make him, this week welcomed leaders from China, India and Iran, among other nations. Then, there was the NATO member.
item.dc:creator: Valerie Hopkins and David Pierson
item.media:description: Turkey’s president, Recep Tayyip Erdogan, left, with President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia on Wednesday in Kazan, Russia.

item.title: Israel Accuses 6 Al Jazeera Journalists of Fighting With Hamas, PIJ
item.description: The news organization strongly denied the accusations, which it said were based on “fabricated evidence” and followed a long history of Israeli hostility toward the network.
item.dc:creator: Aaron Boxerman
item.media:description: An Israeli military vehicle last month outside the building that houses Al Jazeera’s office in Ramallah, in the Israeli-occupied West Bank.

item.title: Mexican Troops Kill 19 Suspected of Being Cartel Members in Sinaloa Shootout
item.description: The killings in the northwestern state of Sinaloa raise questions on whether Mexico’s new president, Claudia Sheinbaum, is taking a tougher approach to cartels.
item.dc:creator: Simon Romero and Emiliano Rodríguez Mega
item.media:description: Federal forces guarding the perimeter of the scene of a shootout on Monday that killed 19 suspected cartel members, on the outskirts of Culiacán, Mexico.

item.title: Trudeau Urged by Fellow Party Members to Step Down
item.description: Liberal Party members fear Justin Trudeau has become so unpopular that it could lead to the party’s defeat in the next election. Mr. Trudeau has said he has no plans to leave.
item.dc:creator: Ian Austen
item.media:credit: Justin Tang/The Canadian Press, via Associated Press
item.media:description: About 20 Liberal Party members criticized Prime Minister Justin Trudeau’s leadership during a meeting, according to Canadian news outlets.

item.title: China May Chafe as North Korea Sends Soldiers to Fight Ukraine
item.description: North Korea’s decision to dispatch troops to help Russia subdue Ukraine may put another Kremlin ally, China, in a tough spot diplomatically.
item.dc:creator: David Pierson
item.media:description: Kim Jong-un, left, and President Xi Jinping of China in 2019. China and North Korea have hailed their 75-year-old diplomatic relations as being as close as “lips and teeth.”

item.title: Family Wins Suit Against Conspiracist Who Called Manchester Bombing a Hoax
item.description: A British court found that a man who called the 2017 attack at an Ariana Grande concert a “fake terrorist incident” had harassed victims and abused media freedom.
item.dc:creator: Lynsey Chutel
item.media:description: Richard Hall in July, after the trial in a harassment suit brought by Martin Hibbert following the 2017 Manchester Arena bombing.

item.title: Gustavo Gutiérrez, Father of Liberation Theology, Dies at 96
item.description: Once considered revolutionary, his notion of empathy and advocacy for the poor has become a central tenet of Catholic social teaching.
item.dc:creator: Bill Friskics-Warren
item.media:description: The Rev. Gustavo Gutiérrez in an undated photo. In his teaching and writings, he asserted that the God of the Jewish and Christian traditions exhibits a preferential commitment to the poor.

item.title: G7 Finalizes $50 Billion Ukraine Loan Backed by Russian Assets
item.description: The economic lifeline is expected to be disbursed by the end of the year.
item.dc:creator: Alan Rappeport and Jenny Gross
item.media:description: Treasury Secretary Janet L. Yellen and Ukranian Finance Minister Sergii Marchenko released a joint statement announcing a $50 billion loan to Ukraine that will be backed by Russian central bank assets.

item.title: Rohingya Refugees Are Stranded at Sea for Days as Residents Reject Them
item.description: The refugees, after weeks on a boat, will be able to disembark temporarily in a town in Indonesia, but residents have refused to let them stay.
item.dc:creator: John Yoon, Rin Hindryati and Muktita Suhartono
item.category: United Nations High Commission for Refugees
item.media:description: Residents of South Aceh, Indonesia, approaching Rohingya refugees stranded on a boat to distribute aid on Wednesday.

item.title: Deadly ‘Terrorist’ Attack on Turkish Aerospace Company Leaves 5 Dead
item.description: Turkey’s interior minister said it was “most probably” the Kurdistan Worker’s Party that carried out the assault on the sprawling Turkish Aerospace Industries complex near Ankara.
item.dc:creator: Ben Hubbard and Safak Timur
item.media:description: Emergency rescue teams and police officers working outside of Turkish Aerospace Industries near Ankara, Turkey, on Wednesday.

item.title: A Modi-Xi Meeting Could Signal a Thaw Between India and China
item.description: A meeting between the two leaders comes just two days after they settled a tense border dispute in the Himalayas. But experts said their long-term geopolitical rivalry would persist.
item.dc:creator: David Pierson, Valerie Hopkins and Alex Travelli
item.media:credit: Sergey Bobylev/BRICS-Rossia2024.ru, via EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: From left, Xi Jinping, China’s top leader, President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia and Prime Minister Narendra Modi of India at the BRICS summit in Kazan, Russia, on Wednesday.

item.title: Ukraine’s Prosecutor General, Andriy Kostin, Resigns Amid Draft Evasion Scandal
item.description: The prosecutor general stepped down after accusations that hundreds of officials obtained fake disability certificates. There have been no public allegations that he was involved in the scheme.
item.dc:creator: Constant Méheut
item.media:description: Ukraine’s prosecutor general, Andriy Kostin, said in a statement that he was responding to an “obviously immoral situation.”

item.title: Gisele Pelicot Testifies in French Rape Case: ‘How Could You Betray Me Like This?’
item.description: Gisèle Pelicot’s ex-husband, Dominique Pelicot, is accused of inviting strangers to sexually assault her while she was drugged and unconscious. The trial has transformed how France discusses sexual violence.
item.dc:creator: Ségolène Le Stradic and Catherine Porter
item.media:description: Gisele Pelicot on Wednesday at the criminal court in Avignon, France, where she took the stand in a trial that has gripped the country.

item.title: Why Is Israel Poised to Attack Iran?
item.description: The two countries have been fighting a shadow war for years. But direct attacks are bringing direct reprisals, or at least plans for them.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Mpoke Bigg
item.media:credit: Avishag Shaar-Yashuv for The New York Times
item.media:description: The remains of a building in Hod Hasharon, Israel, that was hit by Iran’s missile attack this month.

item.title: U.S. Says North Korean Troops Are in Russia to Aid Fight Against Ukraine
item.description: Defense Secretary Lloyd J. Austin III called the situation “very, very serious,” though he said that what the soldiers were doing in Russia was “left to be seen.”
item.dc:creator: Eric Schmitt, David E. Sanger and Anatoly Kurmanaev
item.media:description: For weeks, the Ukrainian and South Korean governments have fueled reports that more than 12,000 North Koreans were training to fight alongside Russian soldiers.

item.title: Trump Accuses U.K. Labour Party of Election Meddling
item.description: Donald Trump’s campaign said Britain’s governing Labour Party had engaged in “blatant foreign interference.” Other British politicians have previously acted in support of Mr. Trump.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.media:description: Donald J. Trump on the campaign trail in Miami on Tuesday. In 2019, he called into a British radio show to back the Conservative Party in an election.

item.title: Here Are the Hezbollah Leaders Israel Has Targeted
item.description: Hashem Safieddine, the presumed successor to Hassan Nasrallah, is the latest Hezbollah leader Israel says it has killed.
item.dc:creator: Aaron Boxerman and Lauren Leatherby

item.title: A U.S. Farming Giant Gets a Message 11 Stories Tall
item.description: Using natural materials from environmental disasters around the country, a Brazilian activist sends a message to a U.S. farming giant.
item.dc:creator: Seth Kugel and Victor Moriyama
item.media:description: A building in downtown São Paulo, Brazil, was painted with a 15,000-square-foot mural of an Indigenous leader, Alessandra Korap.

item.title: White Blobs Wash Up on Canada’s Beaches, Stumping Everyone
item.description: Over a month after the substance began appearing on the southern shores of Newfoundland, a federal agency is still investigating.
item.dc:creator: Alan Yuhas

item.title: Displaced Gazans Brace for Another Harsh Winter
item.description: After a year of war, at least one million people are facing months in the cold. Some said tents, blankets and warm clothes now qualified as luxuries.
item.dc:creator: Hiba Yazbek
item.media:description: In a tent camp for displaced Palestinians in Rafah, in southern Gaza, in February. Many Gazans have now had to flee more than once.

item.title: 4 Can’t-Miss Towns in an Often Overlooked Corner of Japan
item.description: Kyushu, often passed over by international visitors, is rich in crafts, history and culture. Here are four destinations to consider.
item.dc:creator: Rachel Herring

item.title: Tropical Storm Trami Brings Heavy Flooding to the Philippines
item.description: Thousands of people were evacuated from their homes as parts of the country experienced unprecedented flooding, the authorities said.
item.dc:creator: Jin Yu Young and Camille Elemia
item.media:description: Flooding in Naga City, the Philippines, on Wednesday.

item.title: What Is North Korea’s Role in the Russia-Ukraine War?
item.description: North Korea’s supply of munitions has already been critical to the Russian war effort. Now, its troops appear to be poised to join the fight in Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Choe Sang-Hun
item.media:description: A television news report in Seoul on Monday showing soldiers believed to be from North Korea standing in line to receive supplies in Russia.

item.title: Stuffed Into Trucks, 78 Thai Protesters Died. Their Killers Are Still Free.
item.description: Twenty years ago, a massacre in southern Thailand fueled an insurgency that has never stopped. If no one is prosecuted for it by Friday, no one ever will be.
item.dc:creator: Hannah Beech, Ryn Jirenuwat and Ulet Ifansasti
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:credit: Ulet Ifansasti for The New York Times

item.title: Wednesday Briefing
item.description: Early voting starts in all seven swing states.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: Voters lined up to cast their ballots in Stamford, Conn., on Monday.

item.title: Blinken Presses Israel for Truces in Gaza and Lebanon
item.description: The U.S. secretary of state, visiting Israel, said the killing of Hamas’s leader last week could create an opening for peace, and he pushed the Israeli prime minister to allow more aid into Gaza.
item.dc:creator: Michael Crowley, Aaron Boxerman, Hwaida Saad and Thomas Fuller
item.media:credit: Diego Ibarra Sanchez for The New York Times
item.media:description: A medical dispensary was affected by the blast wave from a deadly airstrike in a densely populated neighborhood near Lebanon’s largest public hospital in southern Beirut on Tuesday.

item.title: The UK and Germany Agree on New Defense Pact as Russia Threat Rises
item.description: The two governments said they will coordinate more on defense, with British and German troops conducting joint military exercises on NATO’s eastern border.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Castle
item.media:description: Defense Minister Boris Pistorius of Germany and his British counterpart John Healey in Berlin, in July.

item.title: An Australian Woman Trying to Rescue Her Phone Gets Stuck Between Boulders
item.description: And she was upside down.
item.dc:creator: Kate Christobek
item.media:description: An Australian woman found herself stuck upside down, and wedged between two boulders, in an attempt to retrieve her phone.

item.title: Wednesday Briefing: Casting Doubts on the U.S. Election
item.description: Plus, saving Japan’s most popular rice.
item.dc:creator: Gaya Gupta
item.media:credit: Gabriela Bhaskar for The New York Times
item.media:description: Representative Scott Perry.

item.title: Israel Says It Killed Hashem Safieddine, Considered a Successor to Nasrallah
item.description: Hashem Safieddine, a cousin of Hassan Nasrallah, joined Hezbollah soon after the group was formed and rose quickly in its ranks.
item.dc:creator: Ephrat Livni
item.media:description: Hashem Safieddine at a Hezbollah commander’s funeral in Beirut, Lebanon, in June.

item.title: Yehuda Bauer, 98, Scholar Who Saw Jewish Resistance in Holocaust, Dies
item.description: A leading historian of antisemitism, he countered the prevailing narrative of Jewish victimhood and later pushed back against efforts to diminish the Holocaust’s significance.
item.dc:creator: Clay Risen
item.media:description: Yehuda Bauer, an Israeli scholar, reached audiences beyond his fellow academics with a nuanced reading of the Holocaust as a historical event.

item.title: Despite Global Crises, Gas Prices Slide as U.S. Election Nears
item.description: Fuel prices, which had soared after Russia’s invasion of Ukraine, have dropped to their lowest level since February.
item.dc:creator: Rebecca F. Elliott
item.media:description: Prices at the pump averaged $3.16 nationally on Tuesday, down 11 percent from this time last year.
